docs.lead_paragraph: The article regarding residential underground storage tanks will be helpful in broadening public awareness of an important and historically ignored risk to health and the environment. Contrary to the statement made in the article, the Connecticut Underground Storage Tank Petroleum Clean-up Fund does not pay for clean-up of tanks from residential heating oil tanks. Instead, it covers motor fuel tanks, certain waste oil tanks and commercial heating oil tanks, i.e. those used to store heating oil for distribution to customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Not certain that they are welcome, not even sure they will be safe, black homosexuals are uneasily asking themselves whether they belong inside or outside the Million Man March in Washington. Their anxiety about their role in the Oct. 16 event reflects a deeper question many face every day: by identifying themselves as gay, do they relinquish their ties with the broader black groups, especially the influential religious leaders who publicly condemn homosexuality?

headline.main: Gay Blacks in Quandary Over Farrakhan's March

docs.lead_paragraph: As the science of genetic testing continues to improve, many more healthy people will be found to have a gene or a combination of genes predisposing them to illness ("The DNA We've Been Dealt," by Charles Siebert, Sept. 17). In fact, if every American were to undergo genetic testing, we would discover that each of us possesses some type of faulty DNA. However, such a diagnosis should not also put us at risk of losing our health insurance or our jobs simply because of the possibility of a pre-existing condition. We must enact legislation to prohibit discrimination based on genetic status. JENNIFER L. HOWSE President, March of Dimes Defects Foundation White Plains

docs.lead_paragraph: REPUBLICANS refashioning Medicare and Medicaid have learned many lessons from the death of President Clinton's health care legislation. Their approach reflects a sense that the legislative system is so poisoned by partisanship, sloganeering and 30-second spots that it cannot do anything serious, complex and emotional in a direct and thoughtful way.

headline.main: Bird? Plane? No, It's A Health Bill Flying By

docs.snippet: REPUBLICANS refashioning Medicare and Medicaid have learned many lessons from the death of President Clinton's health care legislation. Their approach reflects a sense that the legislative system is so poisoned by partisanship, sloganeering and...

docs.lead_paragraph: I agree with Paul Starr's comments about the potentially harmful consequences of managed-care expansion as part of the Republicans' program to control Medicare and Medicaid expenditures ("Look Who's Talking Health Care Reform Now," Sept. 3). Corporate America is appropriating health care in this country with the sole purpose of making profit, by brutally squeezing doctors and hospitals financially and by restricting, and even denying, high-tech care to patients. The irony of H.M.O.'s aggressively seeking Medicare patients is evident from the fact that Medicare pays less than 70 percent of actual cost. Obviously, the only way they can make a profit from these patients is to deny care. I can vouch from personal experience that this is increasingly taking place.

In fact, if every American were to undergo genetic testing, we would discover that each of us possesses some type of faulty DNA. However, such a diagnosis should not also put us at risk of losing our health insurance or our jobs simply because of the possibility of a pre-existing condition. We must enact legislation to prohibit discrimination based on genetic status. JENNIFER L. HOWSE President, March of Dimes Defects Foundation White Plains

docs.lead_paragraph: I agree with Paul Starr's comments about the potentially harmful consequences of managed-care expansion as part of the Republicans' program to control Medicare and Medicaid expenditures ("Look Who's Talking Health Care Reform Now," Sept. 3). Corporate America is appropriating health care in this country with the sole purpose of making profit, by brutally squeezing doctors and hospitals financially and by restricting, and even denying, high-tech care to patients. The irony of H.M.O.'s aggressively seeking Medicare patients is evident from the fact that Medicare pays less than 70 percent of actual cost. Obviously, the only way they can make a profit from these patients is to deny care. I can vouch from personal experience that this is increasingly taking place. However, I disagree with Starr's portrayal of the Clinton plan as the solution. I opposed the Clinton proposal largely because of its complex bureaucratic structure and complete governmental domination, not only of decisions regarding the delivery of health care but also, to some extent, medical scientific and educational activities. One of my major concerns with the Clinton proposal, as well as with the changes taking place today, is the threat to the academic health centers.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF ever a company looked after the interests of its home city, Eastman Kodak did. The company's principal founder a century ago, George Eastman, had no children and instead nurtured Rochester like a doting uncle. He gave away more than $100 million -- about $1 billion in today's dollars -- mainly to schools, the University of Rochester and local hospitals. He helped start the organization that became the United Way in Rochester. One year he even paid to remove the tonsils of every child in town. After Eastman died in 1932, his company remained a model of civic sensibility. It resisted the temptation to use its size to negotiate for cheaper medical care for its Rochester employees, a tactic that would mean higher prices for individuals who did not work for Kodak and most small businesses and might push some companies to eliminate health benefits entirely. Many health-care experts have praised the company for an all-for-one and one-for-all spirit that has meant, among other things, that only about 7 percent of area residents do not have health insurance, compared with 15 percent nationally. In all, the move was seen as a fitting legacy of Mr. Eastman, who, according to historians, said "I want to make Rochester the best city in which to live and work."

headline.main: A Doting Uncle Cuts Back, And a City Feels the Pain

docs.snippet: IF ever a company looked after the interests of its home city, Eastman Kodak  did. The company's principal founder a century ago, George Eastman, had no children and instead nurtured Rochester like a doting uncle. He gave away more than $100 million...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Government has proposed that eye surgeons show that the removal of a cataract is medically necessary before Medicare will agree to pay for the operation. An eye surgeons' group expressed concerns about the policy on Friday, saying it could interfere with the relationship between doctor and patient.

headline.main: Plan Proposes Less Coverage For Cataracts
